conversation.content: [warmly] So Marcus, your references were absolutely glowing, especially from DataTech Solutions where you apparently revolutionized their entire security infrastructure in just six months.
Well, I believe in making an immediate impact wherever I land, and their systems were particularly, [chuckles], let's say accessible to improvement.
[slightly puzzled] That's interesting phrasing—accessible—because when I called DataTech's HR department this morning, they had no record of you completing your exit paperwork.
Oh, you know how these big corporations are with their bureaucracy, probably still sitting on someone's desk waiting for signatures. [dismissive laugh]
Actually, they said you still have active credentials in their system, which seems odd for someone who left three months ago, wouldn't you agree?
Sometimes IT departments are slow to revoke access, happens more often than you'd think in this industry. [shifts uncomfortably] Besides, I've been focused on preparing for this opportunity.
[tensing] I see.
Look, I know what you're thinking, but those credentials mean nothing to me now—I'm completely committed to starting fresh here with your innovative blockchain protocols.
[carefully measured] It's funny you mention our blockchain protocols specifically, since we haven't publicly announced that project and it wasn't mentioned in the job posting.
Must have heard about it.
[voice hardening] From whom exactly? Because that information is under strict NDA, and only seven people in this company even know that project exists.
People talk in this industry, you pick things up at conferences, networking events, [laughs nervously], you know how it is.
Marcus, or whatever your real name is, I just received a text from our CTO saying you tried to access our internal servers during your bathroom break twenty minutes ago.
[dropping the act entirely] Your guest WiFi security is pathetic, by the way—took me less than thirty seconds to find the vulnerability in your authentication protocols.
[shakily] Security is already on their way up, and I'm recording this conversation now, so anything you say will be evidence for the authorities.
Evidence of what exactly? That I noticed your laughably weak security during a legitimate interview? [coldly confident] Good luck proving intent in court.
[desperately firm] You won't make it out of this building with any data you've stolen, our systems automatically flag and quarantine any unauthorized access attempts.
Oh, I'm not leaving with your data—I already sent it to three different servers while we've been sitting here chatting about my fabricated references. [standing up slowly]
Those transfers won't complete because we isolated the network the moment you tried to access it, so all you've done is expose yourself for nothing.

You isolated the main network, sure, but your HVAC system runs on a separate subnet that nobody bothered to secure properly. [smiling coldly] Your entire financial database is probably in Beijing by now.

scenario: A corporate recruiter conducts a final interview with a charming candidate who is actually a corporate spy attempting to steal company secrets.
